verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD in the tenth year of Zedekiah king of Judah, which was the eighteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar.
verses.comment: This sets the historical context: the Babylonian siege of Jerusalem. The detailed dating underscores the historicity of the events narrated.

verses.text: At that time, the army of the king of Babylon was besieging Jerusalem, and Jeremiah the prophet was shut up in the court of the guard that was in the palace of the king of Judah.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s imprisonment is evidence of the king’s rejection of God’s word. Compare with other prophetic imprisonments.

verses.text: For Zedekiah king of Judah had imprisoned him, saying, 'Why do you prophesy and say,
verses.comment: Zedekiah’s resistance to prophecy demonstrates human tendency to resist spiritual truths even when confirmed by events. This reflects the importance of authoritative teaching for discerning truth.

verses.text: And Zedekiah king of Judah will not escape from the hand of the Chaldeans, but he will surely be delivered into the hands of the king of Babylon, and will speak with him face to face, and see him eye to eye.
verses.comment: Prophecy of direct personal consequences, reinforcing the reliability of God’s word and the cost of disobedience. See fulfillment in 2 Kings.

verses.text: He will take Zedekiah to Babylon, and there he will remain until I visit him, declares the LORD. If you fight against the Chaldeans, you will not succeed.'
verses.comment: God’s visiting implies judgment and mercy—demanding trust in divine providence even in national distress.

verses.text: Jeremiah said, 'The word of the LORD came to me:
verses.comment: Jeremiah affirms prophetic inspiration—underscored by personal reception of the Lord’s word.

verses.text: 'Behold, Hanamel, the son of Shallum your uncle, will come to you and say,
verses.comment: The right of redemption reflects ancient family law. Jeremiah’s involvement foreshadows restoration, a proto-sacramental act.

verses.text: Then, as the LORD had said, Hanamel my cousin came to me in the court of the guard and said, 'Please buy my field that is at Anathoth in the territory of Benjamin, for you have the right of possession and the right of redemption; buy it for yourself.' Then I knew that this was the word of the LORD.
verses.comment: The confirmation of prophecy strengthens faith in divine providence and the reality of God’s guidance.

verses.text: So I bought the field at Anathoth from Hanamel my cousin, and weighed out the silver to him—seventeen shekels of silver.
verses.comment: The physical transaction gives a tangible sign of hope for future restoration, reminiscent of Abraham’s purchase in Genesis.

verses.text: I signed the deed, sealed it, called in witnesses, and weighed out the silver on the scales.
verses.comment: Careful legal procedures show the seriousness of the act and anticipate fulfillment in future communal restoration.

verses.text: Then I took the deed of purchase, both the sealed copy, containing the terms and conditions, and the open copy.
verses.comment: The two documents—one sealed, one open—hint at hidden and revealed aspects in biblical revelation.

verses.text: And I gave the deed of purchase to Baruch the son of Neriah, son of Mahseiah, in the presence of Hanamel my cousin, and in the presence of the witnesses who had signed the deed, and in the presence of all the Jews sitting in the court of the guard.
verses.comment: Baruch would become an important scribe and teacher, underscoring the importance of tradition and transmission.

verses.text: I instructed Baruch in their presence, saying,
verses.comment: Public instruction indicates communal witness and accountability, a key biblical principle.

verses.text: 'This is what the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, says: Take these deeds, both the sealed and the open copy, and put them in a clay jar, so that they may last for many days.'
verses.comment: Preservation in a jar symbolizes hope for future restoration, as sacred tradition preserves teaching through time.

verses.text: 'For this is what the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, says: Houses and fields and vineyards shall again be bought in this land.'
verses.comment: God promises restoration, underscoring His faithfulness. Buying land even in exile is a prophetic act of faith.

verses.text: After I had given the deed of purchase to Baruch the son of Neriah, I prayed to the LORD, saying:
verses.comment: Prayer follows covenantal action, linking faith, works, and hope. Compare to Jesus’ prayers before important acts.

verses.text: 'Ah, Lord GOD! You made the heavens and the earth by your great power and outstretched arm; nothing is too hard for you.'
verses.comment: Affirmation of God as Creator sets the foundation for His sovereign ability to restore and deliver.

verses.text: You show steadfast love to thousands, but repay the iniquity of fathers into the laps of their children after them. O great and mighty God, whose name is the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: Emphasizes both mercy and justice. The language points to God’s transcendent yet personal nature.

verses.text: Great in counsel and mighty in deed, whose eyes are open to all the ways of mankind, rewarding each according to his ways and according to the fruit of his deeds.
verses.comment: Stresses God’s omniscience and justice: each person’s deeds are consequential.

verses.text: You have shown signs and wonders in the land of Egypt, and to this day in Israel and among all people, and made a name for yourself, as it is this day.
verses.comment: God’s continuing work from the Exodus to present links all ages, affirming divine constancy.

verses.text: And you brought your people Israel out of the land of Egypt with signs and wonders, with a strong hand and outstretched arm, and with great terror.
verses.comment: Exodus referenced as archetypal deliverance; foreshadows ultimate redemption in Christ.

verses.text: You gave them this land, which you swore to their fathers to give them, a land flowing with milk and honey.
verses.comment: Covenant fulfillment—reminds readers God’s promises continue through generations.

verses.text: But they came in and took possession of it, and did not obey your voice or walk in your law; they did nothing of all you commanded them to do. Therefore you have brought all this disaster upon them.
verses.comment: Failure to keep the law leads to exile, reflecting the need for faithful obedience and keeping traditions.

verses.text: Behold, the siege ramps have reached the city to take it, and the city is given over to the Chaldeans who fight against it, because of sword, famine, and plague. What you spoke has happened—look, you see it.
verses.comment: Prophecy fulfilled in detail. The cause-and-effect between sin and suffering is evident.

verses.text: Yet you, O Lord GOD, said to me, 'Buy the field for silver and call witnesses,' though the city is given into the hand of the Chaldeans.
verses.comment: God asks for faith in the midst of visible destruction, highlighting hope grounded on divine promise.

verses.text: The word of the LORD came to Jeremiah:
verses.comment: A new prophetic message follows Jeremiah’s prayer, signifying a dialogical relationship with God.

verses.text: 'Behold, I am the LORD, the God of all flesh. Is anything too hard for me?'
verses.comment: Echoes Abraham’s story, emphasizing omnipotence—God’s ability to save and restore is unlimited.

verses.text: Therefore, thus says the LORD: 'Behold, I am giving this city into the hand of the Chaldeans, and into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and he shall take it.'
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over nations is clear, even using pagan kings for judgment.

verses.text: 'The Chaldeans who are fighting against this city will enter it and set it on fire, and burn it, together with the houses where people have offered incense to Baal on their roofs and poured out drink offerings to other gods, provoking me to anger.'
verses.comment: Idolatry and syncretism are direct causes for judgment—warning against blending truth with error.

verses.text: 'For the children of Israel and the children of Judah have done nothing but evil in my sight from their youth. For the children of Israel have only provoked me to anger by the work of their hands, declares the LORD.'
verses.comment: Israel’s historical disobedience highlights need for renewal—a theme fulfilled in the New Covenant.

verses.text: 'This city has aroused my anger and wrath from the day it was built to this day, so that I will remove it from my sight.'
verses.comment: Divine patience meets limit as Jerusalem’s persistent sin brings exile.

verses.text: 'Because of all the evil of the children of Israel and the children of Judah that they have done to provoke me to anger—their kings, their officials, their priests, their prophets, the men of Judah and the citizens of Jerusalem.'
verses.comment: Leaders’ failure carries communal responsibility—important for understanding spiritual authority.

verses.text: 'They have turned to me their back and not their face; and though I taught them again and again, they would not listen or receive instruction.'
verses.comment: Deliberate rejection of revelation implies culpability—emphasizes need for humble submission.

verses.text: 'They set up their abominations in the house which is called by my name, to defile it.'
verses.comment: Sacrilegious idolatry in the temple points to danger of profaning sacred spaces—a theme taken up by Christ in the cleansing of the temple.

verses.text: 'They built the high places of Baal in the valley of Ben Hinnom, to offer up their sons and daughters to Molech, though I never commanded it, nor did it enter my mind, that they should do this abomination, to make Judah sin.'
verses.comment: Child sacrifice represents the worst violation of God’s law; Gehenna later becomes a symbol of judgment in the New Testament.

verses.text: 'Now therefore, says the LORD, the God of Israel, concerning this city of which you say,
verses.comment: The triple judgment emphasizes the thoroughness of exile, but context admits the possibility of restoration.

verses.text: 'See, I will gather them out of all the lands to which I have driven them in my anger, wrath, and great indignation. I will bring them back to this place and make them dwell in safety.'
verses.comment: Foreshadows New Exodus, gathering and unity; spiritually anticipated in future gatherings of all nations.

verses.text: 'They will be my people, and I will be their God.'
verses.comment: Echoes covenant promise, ultimately realized in full communion with God through Christ.

verses.text: 'I will give them one heart and one way, that they may fear me always, for their good and the good of their children after them.'
verses.comment: Promise of one heart and way anticipates spiritual unity and a single faith; see Acts 4:32 for unity among believers.

verses.text: 'I will make with them an everlasting covenant, that I will not turn away from doing good to them. And I will put my fear in their hearts, so that they will not turn away from me.'
verses.comment: Everlasting covenant points to permanence; see Hebrews and the institution of the sacraments as fulfillment.

verses.text: 'I will rejoice in doing them good, and I will plant them in this land in faithfulness, with all my heart and soul.'
verses.comment: God’s delight in His people foreshadows Jesus rejoicing over His disciples. Divine love is whole-hearted.

verses.text: 'For thus says the LORD: Just as I have brought all this great disaster upon this people, so I will bring upon them all the good that I promise them.'
verses.comment: God’s promises are guaranteed, even after punishment—justice and mercy remain in harmony.

verses.text: 'Fields shall be bought in this land of which you say,
verses.comment: Promise of return and ordinary commerce is sign of restored blessing—material and spiritual restoration.

verses.text: 'Fields shall be bought for silver, and deeds shall be signed, sealed, and witnessed in the land of Benjamin, in the places around Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, the cities of the hill country, the cities of the Shephelah, and the cities of the Negev; for I will restore their fortunes, declares the LORD.'
verses.comment: Restoration repeats over all the land—universal promise of redemption, spatial and spiritual, prefiguring the spread of true worship everywhere.
